content:
Attendees of the Standing Rock rally hold signs against the pipeline Oct PERIOD  in front of the Oklahoma State Capitol building PERIOD

The Dakota Access Pipeline will not be routed underneath a lake near the Standing Rock Sioux tribe after the Army Corps of Engineers announced today it will not approve an easement that would allow it to do so PERIOD

JoEllen Darcy the assistant secretary of the U.S PERIOD Army said she based her decision to not route the pipeline underneath Lake Oahe in North Dakota off of the need to explore alternate routes for the crossing the release says PERIOD It also says tribal officials have repeatedly expressed concerns about the risk that the pipeline could rupture and endanger the tribes water supply PERIOD

The proposed crossing underneath Lake Oahe is half a mile south of the Standing Rock Sioux tribes reservation PERIOD For weeks members of the tribe and others have protested the construction of the pipeline many of the protests turning violent PERIOD

On Nov PERIOD  the Morton County North Dakota Sheriffs Department also said it plans to fine anyone who brings supplies to those protesting the pipeline PERIOD

OU students and more protested the pipeline in Norman Nov PERIOD  by walking down Main Street with signs that read phrases such as  and  Days earlier hundreds gathered in Oklahoma City to protest as well PERIOD

The Undergraduate Student Congress also passed a resolution Nov PERIOD  supporting the efforts of the pipeline protesters PERIOD It acknowledges the grievances faced by members of the Standing Rock Sioux tribe and encourages students to get involved in the fight against the pipelines construction PERIOD

title: Dakota Access Pipeline won't pass through Standing Rock Sioux territory | News | oudaily.com
name: University of Oklahoma
